string.text: I’ve come to see you.
Very well.
Good luck stalker.
Thanks.
You need to find the Wish Granter. It is located somewhere in Chernobyl NPP and will not be easy to get to. This is your only way out of here.
I want to find the Wish Granter.

Sure easy, it’s up in Chernobyl, the next bus leaves in twenty minutes, hehe… Listen stalker, there have been many people before you that have come here looking to find the Wish Granter, you know what they all have in common? They are all feeding the worms right now. The Wish Granter is just a legend, it doesn’t exist. Even if it did exist do you know what your wish would be if you found it? That you never went looking for it in the first place. You want to get rich, is that it? You don’t need to wish for your fortune. Someone like you can make plenty of money here in the Zone if you are smart. Here is what I will do for you; show me your PDA… Ah, there, I’ve loaded in a list of contacts, people here in the Zone who I know are looking to have work done. Go visit them when you are ready, some of them pay well. In the meantime, ask around camp, there is plenty of work here, heck, I even have some jobs I need done from time to time. It’s an honest living, at least as honest as it gets here in the Zone.

Thank you stalker. Listen, I hear you came here looking to find the Wish Granter, yes? I have important news for you. The Wish Granter does exist, it is not merely a legend. If you are brave or foolish enough to go looking for it now may be your only chance. The Monolith are congregating in Pripyat leaving only a few to defend Chernobyl. Even still, it will not be easy to get to. The entire area is flooded with anomalies that will rip you to shreds, rad levels that will kill you standing, and psi fields that will turn your mind to soup. Make sure you are prepared. Good luck to you stalker.
I want to join Duty.

Excellent! You have built quite a reputation for yourself stalker, we could use someone like you. Very well, let’s get right to business. I need someone who knows how to navigate the Zone. We have many friends in various areas throughout the Zone who need our assistance but not many of our soldiers are able to reach them. I will send you to them They will tell you what they need done. Welcome aboard.

Good job. There is one other thing I need you to do, well, that needs to be done. You must find the Wish Granter. The Monolith are guarding it deep within Chernobyl NPP. It must be destroyed. Listen carefully, I know exactly what you must do. The Wish Granter grants wishes, right? That is its weakness. Find it and wish for it to be destroyed. Do not fall into the temptation to wish for your own selfish desires, this is for the greater good. Find the Wish Granter and wish it out of existence. This is what you must do. Good luck to you.
You wanted to see me, bro?

Yes, I have a very important assignment for you. We can’t expect to protect the Zone from exploitation if we stay holed up in these warehouses. I need you to travel the Zone and help spread our influence. I’ve loaded a list of contacts for you to meet with into your PDA. Visit them and see if there is anything you can do to for them. This will strengthen our local relations and increase our allies to help keep the Zone free, and could earn you some sweet cash in the process.

Thanks. Listen, you want to keep the Zone free, right? You’re going about it the wrong way. Spreading good will one person at a time will do you no good. Everyone here is corrupt, they only care about their own needs. Even if you manage to change that opinion in someone, they will be dead soon, so what’s the point? The solution is obvious. The Brain Scorcher has been disabled, and the path to the Wish Granter is open, but few people know that yet. If you can be the first to get there you can use it to wish for the Zone to protect itself. Find the Wish Granter, but avoid the temptation to use it for your own desires. It will not be easy, but if you truely want to preserve the Zone, this is what you must do. Good luck to you.
I’m ready for my mission.

Good, good. You know how important this mission is. You cannot fail. I regret we can’t tell you any more about it, but the secrecy of this mission must be so absolute that there are parts even you must not know about. Just do as we planned. Meet with the people we discussed, their contact information is stored in your PDA. When the time is right all will be revealed. You will know exactly what you must do. Good luck to you.

Good work. You have done very well. Now is the time to fulfill your mission. The path to Chernobyl has been cleared. At the heart of the reactor lies the Monolith, the Wish Granter. Find it. Then you know what you must do.
You wanted to see me, boss?

Oh, yes, yes. Good! I’m glad you’re here. I have an important assignment for you. I want you to travel the Zone and learn as much as you can. There is so much out there we haven’t yet discovered. Consider it… exploratory research. I’ve provided you with a list of contacts who will take care of you along your journey. Visit them, they can provide you with work or food or shelter. Explore and be curious! Be bold and adventurous! I expect your research will vastly increase our understanding of the Zone.

Thanks. So, tell me, you’ve traveled the Zone and seen all of its wonders. But you haven’t yet studied the biggest prize, have you? I speak of course of the Wish Granter. You can reach it now, if you prepare yourself. It will not be easy. Lethal levels of radiation, psi fields, mutants, and Monolith snipers all await you. But if you truely desire to understand the Zone, you must travel to where it all began, the NPP itself. Good luck to you.
So what can you tell me about our employer?

Pff.. Who knows? No one seems to know much about him. All I know is his money is good and he’s got a lot of it. But we gotta work to get it. This place is a living hell from what I’ve heard, a real life waking nightmare. Hell, with the shit I’ve already seen I believe it. Doesn’t matter though, ain’t nothing out there I can’t kill. Anyway, enough bullshit. You’ve got your job to do and I got mine. You got your list of contacts to meet? Good. Stay frosty out there. Good luck.

Thank you. Listen, I have a message for you. It comes straight from your employer. It seems you have impressed him greatly. He has a special mission for you and only you. You must find the Wish Granter. Once you do you must utter the following phrase; “princeps magis opulentus.” Do this exact thing and your prince will reward you handsomely.
Reporting for duty, sir.

Welcome to hell soldier. You must have pissed someone off pretty bad to pull this assignment. Well, listen to me and you’ll stay alive. Keep your head on a swivel. Everyone and everything out here is trying to kill you. Stay low in a firefight and find good cover. Trust no one. Shoot first and ask questions later. Your tour of duty will take you all over the Zone, most of the time no one will be there to help you. Rely on your survival training. Meet with the contacts loaded into your PDA and they will give you your orders. Just complete your tour of duty and stay alive and you’ll get to go home. You are dismissed.

Thank you soldier. You have done well for me, now I will do something for you, although you may not want to hear it. You are expecting to rotate out of here soon, yes? I’m afraid your commanders have other ideas. The cordon has closed in and has been locked down, nothing and no one are able to get in or out of the Zone anymore, including the military. You’ve been left here to die, and even your corpse will be left for worm food. You can’t even escape in a body bag. But all hope is not lost for you, if you are daring. There is only one way left for you to get out of here, and it lies in Chernobyl. Buried deep within the NPP is the Wish Granter. If you can find it, and if you survive, you can use it to wish your way out of here. It is your only hope soldier. Good luck to you.
You want me to work for you? What’s in it for me?

There are people here in the Zone who need things done for them. Some of these things cannot be done, shall we say; inside of regular channels. So they come to me. I arrange to take care of business for them and in return I expect them to pay me a very hefty sum. I will give you a list of these people. Go to them, do what they ask, and collect the payment. All I require is you give me 20 percent of what they pay when you are finished. Any money you make on the side while you’re out there is your’s to keep. Good deal, yes? It’s more money than you would make pick-pocketing and looting stashes and sticking up rookies I guarantee. Just don’t double-cross me, understand? I know everyone in this place and they can be very motivated to make examples of anyone who tries to rip me off. Now get out of my sight. I have some important business to attend to.

Wadda you want? .. *hic* .. Oh, itz you .. *hic* .. I know you. Hey, didja do that thing I wanted for ya to do? Ahhh, I knew you wouldn’t let me down buddy, you’re always buddy .. *hic* .. Here, join me inna drink.. inna.. where’z my bottle? .. *hic* .. It’z a celelelebration! Cus I’m gonna be rizssh! .. *hic*
What can I do to serve the almighty Monolith?

There is much work to be done, my brother. The Zone must be purged of the infidels. We must keep control of the mutant population. Your brothers need food and weapons. You will report to your Monolith elders and we will give you your assignments. You must do your part. Praise the Monolith, and may the Monolith bless you.

You have done well, and have proven your faith with the many deeds you have done. You have earned the privilege of meeting the almighty Monolith. Not many are blessed enough to look into the eyes of god. Prepare an offering and pledge your devotion to our lord. The journey into the Sarcophagus will not be easy, and you must go alone. But listen, if your faith is pure the Monolith will call to you and show you the way.
I want to change factions.
I’ll do it.
See me when it’s done.
Okay.
I need a certificate for being present in the Zone.
All right. Here’s the money.
Just a moment… Here you go. Try not to miss the deadline.
Okay.
I need a truce with the bandits.
Here’s the money.
Just wait a moment and I’ll send the information… Done. For three days, you’ll be left alone. You can go about your business in peace.
Thank you.
I need a truce with the mercenaries.
Here’s the money.
Just wait a moment and I’ll send the information… Done. For a week, you’ll be left alone. You can go about your business in peace.
Thank you.
I want to ask you something.
Never mind.
Okay.
Thanks.
About what?
Sure.
Go ahead.
Yes?
I already told you.
I don’t know much more.
That’s all I know. Ask someone else.
God damn, man. You got a hard-on for me? Ask someone else.
Not much more I can tell ya, man.
You can keep asking the same shit, but I got nothing more to say.
Drop the subject, dude.
Some other time, man.
Drop by later and maybe I can tell you more.
Eh. I ain’t getting into much more depth. You have any other questions?
Bro, if I had all the answers, I wouldn’t be in this shit dump.
Good question. If you find out, share that info with me, will you?
You are putting me on the spot here, man. I don’t know.
Hell if I know, man.
There’s always something going on in the Zone, but nothing I would like to share with you.
I’ve nothing to tell you, man. Nobody tells me shit.
You’re asking the wrong guy.
I’d like to know that too.
Sorry. I can’t help you.
Sorry. Got nothing.
How’s it going?
Hey, man. What’s up?
Hello. How are you?
Hello, brother.
Greetings, stalker.
I’m good. What’s up?
Hello.
What’s up?
What do you want?
So far, so good. You?
Been better days. What do you need?
Good day!
Yeah, what is it?
Piss off, stalker.
What do you want?
Okay, just one damn question, but all I better see after is asses and elbows.
What do you need, stalker?
Help, please… I’m dying…
Help me out, bro… Oh, God, it hurts!
Friend, medkit… Give me a medkit…
Bro… Bro, save me!
Friend, the first aid kit… The kit!
Stalker, help me… Give me a medkit…
I’m hurt… Help!
Screw this place!
Medkit!
Help, dude!
Medkit! Quick!
Help! I’m dying!
I need first aid, guys! Hurry up!
I need a medkit! Help!
Medic!
Hey, bro, can you share your first aid kit?
Get me a damn doctor! Urgh, have you got a medkit? Please! I need it!
What do you know about anomalies or artefacts?
You know anything about anomalies or artefacts?
What can you tell me about anomalies or artefacts?
I don’t feel comfortable telling you anything.

Well, the Burner anomaly can be a bit difficult to see; even during daylight, there’s only a faint haze. If you piss it off with one of your bolts, it’ll shoot a tall pillar of flame into the air, so keep your distance.

Comet anomalies are a lot like the Burner, both fire-y, only… this is a big floating ball of flame that flies about wherever you might find it. Best to duck and dive about when near those things… otherwise, you’ll get your ass burnt off.
Vortex’s are some sorta floating thing that drag everything nearby towards it and start spinning it around. If you get caught up in that, you’ll get splattered all over the place.

Springboards are these floating gravity balls… but you touch them, and whoosh: it’ll blow up right in your face. You’ll find them everywhere, and you’ll probably hear them humming to you before you see them.

You should keep an eye out for Whirligigs; dirt and leaves blowing about are a pretty good sign there’s one nearby. I saw a flesh get pulled in to one when I was at the Cordon… Started spinning around ’til it just tore itself apart from the force.

The Fruit Punch is a glowing puddle of green shit on the floor which will hiss and spit at you. Might be able to get a good artefact from it if you’re brave enough to get up next to it, but it’ll melt your face off if you get a little too comfy.

Burnt Fuzz anomalies are usually found outdoors. They look like moss or vines, hanging down like curtains… Shoots these spores in your face if you run up and touch it, like some kinda defence mechanism.
Look out for green Gas anomalies floating and wandering over the ground. It’s acidic, and if you end up taking a stroll into the stuff, it’ll start trying to eat away at your legs.
Keep your eyes peeled for Gas Cloud anomalies. If you see a flying ball of acid darting around, go around or under that thing, or you’ll wind up looking like a flesh.

You ever see those giant electrical puddles on the ground? Electros is what the scientists call them. Most of them will only go off if something goes over and introduces itself, but half the time, I swear, they explode even when there’s nothing there. Some of them seem to disappear for a few seconds, too. If you can time it right, then you can walk right past them, no problem.

Few days ago, I came across this floating ball of electricity. I think the eggheads named them after that electricity guy… Tesla, or whatever his name was. Anyway, I was in this hallway and it was pacing up and down… no, flying up and down. Had to time it right and go bit by bit through the room, hiding behind old junk and letting it keep passing me.

You know how that Forester guy over in the Red Forest says he got stuck in one of those Space anomalies? Said it was like an open field of grass… Endless with no way out. That was until he found a Compass artefact which showed him the exit, just like the rumours say they do. He says he got mugged by a bunch of bandits not long after and lost it, but personally, I think the old coot’s just going senile.

Few years ago, Clear Sky went after a stalker headed for the power plant. We all know how that ended, but there was this merc with them: Scar. The few of the people that survived the mess say these anomalies started showing up all over the place that let him teleport closer to the guy he was after, like the Zone was helping him. Weird shit.

Ever seen any jagged rocks sticking out from the ground with a bunch of warped trees nearby? Me neither, but I’ve heard there’s something like that over in the Red Forest. Apparently, those Symbiont anomalies are pretty good for artefacts; you can get all kinds of stuff out of them.

The scientists are scratching their heads over those Fault anomalies. They’re these cracks, huge fractures in the ground; usually have a whole bunch of Comets and other anomalies underneath them. They’ve no idea if they’re just anomaly fields or if there’s something else to them. When was the last time you heard of an earthquake in this part of the world?

You don’t always have to crawl through anomalies to find artefacts. Someone told me a story of how they found an artefact in an open field. A stalker’s detector starts going crazy, so he figures it has a blown capacitor. He replaces it, it starts working, and lo and behold, an artefact practically falls into his hands.

Watch out for Whirligig and Vortex anomalies, man. Absolutely dangerous, even for an experienced stalker. It will snatch you up and violently shake you around like a rag doll. One time, I saw this dude get caught up in one. I thought I would be getting me a new pair of boots, but this sucker started running as fast as he could. I couldn’t believe this shit. He dove right outta there before he was shredded.

Ever heard of a Gravi? Looks like something a pseudodog would shit out, but it’s metallic. Scientists are willing to pay well for these things. I wouldn’t bother, though; anyone who touches one of those will be glowing for a month. There are similar artefacts called Goldfish. I’m sure you can guess what it looks like, ’cause it’s even more rare. Better keep it to yourself if you find one, though.

The first thing you should try to get your hands on is at least a Medusa. The more radiation-absorbing an artefact you can get, like a Wrenched or a Bubble, the safer you will be. I’ve already seen too many stalkers slowly dying of radiation without being able to reach a medic, or even too poor to buy themselves some anti-rads.

I can’t figure out what the scientists make from the artefacts they buy from the Zone. All I know is cash for these seems to be limitless. And whatever if the thing is positive or not… The more powerful an artefact is, the more they pay.

Have you ever heard of the Glass? It looks like a dirty and yet shiny glass ball. Man, this thing could stop bleeding from the worst wounds if you have something to cure its radiation. Don’t sell it if you find one.

I’ve heard of something called the Compass several times. It would appear that this artefact would be almost perfect, apart from the radiation it emits. It was rumoured that it protects against many of the risks of the Zone, but on top of that, it would seem that the wearer naturally finds some paths through the worst anomaly fields.
What more can I tell you other than the stories everybody hears here around campfires? If you want advice, just take care about everything.

I often hear stories about some untouched, wonderful artefact fields that could make a poor, inexperienced stalker a rich man. My opinion is that all of these are traps. How can anyone logically think about getting into such anomaly mazes, just out of greed?… Especially knowing that the anomalies can move, and so, close any exits… If you think about it, the little shiny things that attract you to themselves are perfect in their roles.

All I can say is to be really careful about the gear you choose and why. Don’t expect to go for an artefact hunt with a heavy shielded exo. It can become like a pin with electric fields and will melt on you like hot chocolate in chemical ones.

The hardest thing about artefact hunting is starting. If you can grab a protective artefact, you can then explore other anomalies of the same type easily; then sell your findings, get better gear, and so on. Plus, the more you cross them, the more you’ll know how to do it. Just be really careful. From your beginner’s hours to an experienced stalker, if you come to be one, the Zone always keep new traps.

Be in good shape; that’s the clever advice I can give to you. The Zone can be really harsh and outright exhaustive sometimes. You’ll have better chances in surviving long trips and their inevitable hazards if your body is ready for it. It’s true about anomalies, too; do you think you can cross a chemical field with a pack of mutants at your back, after a night of vodka abuse?

Many stalkers, particularly regular users of vodka, don’t pay attention to the psychic dangers of the Zone… and so, they kick the bucket when they have to get out of a psi-field. It’s a good thing to find some psi-protection; the Moonlight artefact can make the difference in decisive moments. Plus, it can be useful against a controller, for instance.

Keep in mind that some people here don’t bother to chase artefacts. They prefer to hunt humans… In other words, pay attention to the bandits. It’s well known they have artefact orders for their black market. Don’t let too many people know what artefacts you have, either.
Did you know that artefacts are almost indestructible? Sometimes it’s better to shoot at the artefact to make it jump out of the anomaly, instead of just being sucked directly into it.

I wish I had known the Zone that I’ve heard about: the one that was like a no man’s land. How can we get rich these days, when, after every emission, a bunch of stalkers rush to every anomaly field to pick up their flowers?

Why should I give you any advice, more so when it comes to the business many of us use for making money? Well, get a good detector and help yourself. The scientists will probably sell you what you’re looking for.

Many newcomers dream about “the artefact that makes you rich.” Even if the Zone can be fruitful, it often takes a long time and a serious amount of money to get the gear that lets you head to the most dangerous and productive areas. Of course, you can be lucky… but knowing this place, I wouldn’t count so much on that.

You know where the dredge station is? It’s been battered up by gravitational anomalies, but not too bad for an experienced stalker. Just keep throwing bolts as usual. There’s also radiation, inside and out… It’s like being next to a massive chunk of enriched uranium.

Sometimes you don’t even have to jump into anomalies to scare up an artefact. I’ve been told of an artefact found out in the open field. This one stalker had a detector that started acting up, so he decided to change the batteries. As soon as he did, the detector shows a reading, and bam: an artefact basically drops in his hands. Lucky bastard, eh? That’s the Zone for you: sometimes it punishes you, and sometimes it rewards you.

The surest place is the acid swamp. It’s full of gravitational anomalies, but those are easy to spot. Just keep your eye on the water surface and you can’t go wrong. Gas anomalies are more of a pain, because there’s basically no air to breathe. Getting squirted by one is no fun, believe me. That thing eats through a vest faster than sulphuric acid.

There’s an old substation here, also called the Iron Forest. You’ll understand why when you see it. Some people claim to have found clusters of artefacts in that area after emissions. It’s not all that dangerous: mainly electric anomalies and a bit of radiation… There are also a few poltergeists that will bury you in all kinds of crap if you don’t hide in time.

There are plenty of heat anomalies at the burnt farmstead up on the hill. People find fire artefacts there. Look in the houses: whichever’s got the most anomalies in it after an emission, that’s where the artefacts will be.

There are probably lots of them in the caves under the burnt farmstead. If you walk on the hill with a detector, it won’t stop beeping. Getting to them is easy enough: just jump in through the gap from above. Getting out is the hard part, what with all the anomalies down there. Mostly vortexes and acid. Some also claim to have seen something resembling a comet in that gap. A whole mix of dangers, to be sure, but that means the artefacts are probably mixed as well.

Have you seen a Circus anomaly? It’s a huge springboard anomaly with two comets going round and round… Quite a sight to behold. Behold it from a distance, though, because Circuses are hot as hell, with lots of heat anomalies. It’s got plenty of artefacts, too, but they’re guarded by a nasty fire poltergeist that tries to roast you up when you come near.

There’s this place they call Scar, where the ground looks like it’s been hacked with an axe. People have found artefacts there, but once you go in there, something weird starts to happen. That thing hits your brains so hard you almost forget how to breathe, let alone try to get your ass out of there.

If you’re interested in gravitational artefacts, look for them in the Fang anomaly. The place is easy to spot; anomalies have done a job on the terrain and taken half the hill clean off. A few caves opened up in the hill and were immediately settled by snorks, but thankfully, they rarely head outside.

There’s a spot in Zaton where heat anomalies emerged underwater. They call it “Boiler” because there’s steam and stuff coming out from the ground. If you think steam is nothing, think again. Seasoned stalkers say this kind of vapour anomaly hits you at least as hard as a regular heat anomaly… if not harder. The temperature may be a bit lower, but it grills you longer. As for artefacts, there are regular ones there; the fire kind.

They say there’s a nice spot in the quarry with lots of artefacts, though not scant on anomalies either. Down at the bottom, there are so many bubbles from gas anomalies… It hurts your eyes, even with a gas mask on.
The Ash Heap is at the old graveyard near Kopachy. There are lots of heat anomalies, and also some zombies from time to time. People try to avoid the place, but they do find artefacts there.

They say artefacts have been found in the parking lot. Still got vehicles from the first Chernobyl disaster; those babies give the rad counter heartburn. In addition, the lot is full of electrical anomalies as well.

In the Putrid Grove, where trees are all warped from acid. People who’ve been there say it’s full of gas anomalies. There’s so much gas in the air that you can’t see straight, but with enough experience, you can find the artefacts you’re looking for.

If you’re after artefacts, go for the acid kind. The best place to get those is the Concrete Bath. You won’t have a lot of competition: no one likes that place because of its proximity to the Jupiter building.

Not far from the Jupiter plant, a piece of the road fell through. They call this place Bitumen, because that’s where the pavement melted. There are many anomalies in the gap: heat anomalies mixed with gravitational ones. And since it’s two kinds of anomalies, the artefacts must be of a different kind, too.

There’s a small harbour beyond the cement plant called Fen, which has turned into a terrible stinking marsh full of gas anomalies. It’s not even really water any more… More like acid. People have found artefacts there before, but the place is also teeming with monsters.

Look in the old cement plant; lots of anomalies, but it’s worth it. Sure, there are spots where artefacts are easier to come by, but so’s the competition. Here, your only competition consists of hamsters, and that’s only if you go down in the basement.

You should look near the Oakpine. That’s that thing growing between the hills, above the gas anomalies. Everyone’s been calling it that since some geek identified the bark from that tree as both pine and oak. If you want to search for artefacts there, you’ll need good chemical protection. Take lots of ammo, too, because those hills are home to packs and packs of dogs.

I’ve heard from seasoned stalkers that artefacts sometimes move outside of anomalies. Your detector starts going “peep,” you take it out, but there’s nothing there. That means a “nomadic” artefact walked past you… but it’s no use chasing it, because only the Zone decides who to reward it with.
No one has looked for artefacts in Pripyat yet. Everyone I know has only been here a short while, so they stay cautious.
I don’t know if anyone knows the good spots. Pripyat is poorly explored so far.
I’d look in the underground tunnels. They say there are tons of them underneath the city.

Not much is known about these parts… Garry’s stories, mostly. He says there’s a place here where a huge grapevine grows out of an acid anomaly, as tall as a ten-story building. He might be pulling our leg, but I’d check out that vine for artefacts just in case.
What’s new in the Zone?
You know what’s going on around here?
I’m looking for information.
I don’t have any information.

The army set up a base in Agroprom; right in the middle of it. Place is packed with dogs and other mutants just running around with nothing stopping them. By itself, it ain’t so special, but there’s this huge subterranean underground full of anomalies sitting right below it. If it weren’t for the soldiers, I’d be down there right now hauling a whole bunch of artefacts.

The Agroprom underground is sat underneath the research institute buildings. I hear different things about it all the time: one day I hear it’s full of anomalies, perfect for artefact hunting, and next it’s barren, nothing but mutants… Next I hear, the place is full of controllers and poltergeists. Me? I don’t even know what to believe. Damned if I’ll be going down there with all the jar-heads patrolling aboveground, though.

You ever been to Rostok? You’ve got the 100 Rads and the arena just across the street from each other to keep you busy. A real shining star in the middle of the Earth’s asshole, don’t you think? Whole place used to be a giant factory complex, so Duty found it perfect to set up their base of operations there. I’m not complaining, though; they do a good job of keeping all the filth out. You won’t see any bandits or mutants about the place.

The Cordon is quieter than most other areas. Most stay at the Rookie village north of the actual military cordon until they have enough gear and experience to head deeper into the Zone. You’ll find Nimble and Sidorovich there too, Nimble will help you get hold of really high-end gear, best of the best, while Sid sits down in his bunker where he’ll sell you smuggled in goods; food, medical supplies, you get the idea.

The Darkscape connects the southern edge of the Dark Valley with the tunnel in the east of the Cordon. Full of forest, mutants, bandits, and anomalies, but somehow you’ll always find a group of loners down there for whatever reason. I wouldn’t stick too close to the road, either; you’ll leave glowing from the radiation, or you’ll get torn apart by a pack of dogs.

The Dark Valley is a forbidding place, filled with rusting wrecks and crumbling buildings. There are a few anomalies nearby where you can try your luck artefact hunting… but the bandits occupy the factory in the north, so good luck not getting mugged afterwards.

The Dead City is right between Yantar and Limansk with a whole gathering of mercs right in the middle. There’s gotta be a huge stash of guns and meds in there somewhere… Where else do they keep all their shit? If you wanna get through the place without getting your ass beat, I heard you could sneak about through the sewers. Not much else I can tell you, bro.

You know they dumped all their ruined machines and vehicles after the disaster in Garbage, right? Loners and bandits are always trying to get the best loot, shooting at each other all the time while trying not to get chewed up by the mutants. There’s a whole grouping of anomalies in the little vehicle graveyard, too. You’re almost guaranteed an artefact if you get there right after an emission hits.

Ever been to the Generators? They’re found up north beyond the power plant. There are six of them in a ring formation with the old war lab not far south. Not much to look at besides a few old labs, but plenty of mutants to keep your gun busy while you’re there, if that’s your thing.

We occupy nearly all of the Deserted Hospital. Most of the paths through that lead further towards the Chernobyl NPP are fenced off by a machine gun emplacements or some other shit. No stalkers will be getting through there any time soon.

Jupiter is still unsettled, much like Zaton… and since they turned on the Brain Scorcher, it’s almost impossible to get to there without putting your neck on the line. If you don’t wanna get your brains scrambled, then your only path is through the Red Forest… Not that you’ll make it through alive with mutants and anomalies hiding behind all the trees.

Thinking of travelling through the Jupiter underground? You’ll need a suit with a closed cycle respiratory module due to the harsh conditions within, but it’ll let you go right beneath Pripyat directly to the Outskirts so you can avoid all the cultists.

Limansk is an empty place, full of derelict buildings and vehicles. I heard the mercs tried to push through it from the Dead City recently, although they didn’t make it that far… Lost too many men to the anomalies and mutants.

The Great Swamps are mostly a wet and irradiated hole in the ground, but you’ll find a few abandoned buildings and settlements here and there, which are worth looting. There’s also the Clear Sky base somewhere towards the south. Quite an isolated place.

Ever heard about the army warehouses? Freedom set up their headquarters there after they got their ass handed to them by bandits a couple years back; claim they’re protecting the Zone by defending the barrier there, which leads to Radar. Complete nonsense, if you ask me. If the bandits could tear ’em a new one, you can be sure the Monolith would have already.
The Monolith are holed up in Pripyat, from what I’ve heard. No way of getting through all of the anomalies and mutants with them shooting at you the whole time.

You should consider checking out the Pripyat outskirts; plenty of anomalies to make you rich, and you won’t even have to go through the plaza to get there, either. Just take the underground passage through Jupiter, which, by the way, is clear of any Monolithians.

Those bastards turned the Brain Scorcher back on when they took the Radar. There’s no way to the other side of the Zone now, unless you feel like being fed to the local wildlife or being turned into one of those zombies like the ones you see in Yantar.

More and more stalkers have gotten themselves killed trying to get through the Red Forest since the takeover of the Radar. Forester can only do so much with their equipment to help, and I don’t feel like sticking my balls in the frying pan for the sake of a few artefacts.

The Wild Territory used to be the site of a rather large manufacturing plant, but now the place is swarming with monsters and is full of anomalies. Only real reason to go through there is if you want to get to Rostok or if you’re desperate for loot, and there are plenty of other safe routes to use instead.

What would you wish for? What’s the one thing you really want? If you help me find the Wish Granter, then maybe it will come true. I’ve heard it’s buried under the power plant somewhere. Do you think that maybe that’s what the Monolith are fighting to protect?

Yantar is morbid and sodden with death. Anyone who dares to go too far goes insane. Zombies and snorks are all over the place just waiting to introduce themselves to you. They keep spewing out of that factory, and half of the time when the scientists gun them down, they realise it’s one of their own men who was shooting at them. It’s real fucked.

Hey, stalker, if you’re ever up in Zaton, you should check out the Skadovsk; it’s this old rusty ship run by this stalker calling himself Beard, or at least he likes to think he does. You can find somewhere to sleep, repair your gear, and sell all your loot. Owl’s always interested in buying those extra PDAs off of your hands if they have any nice info on them.

Hey, listen, have you caught word of a guy called the Black Digger? I heard that he used to be a really lucky fella. Got himself a nice amount of roubles and a plethora of nice items as well. Some say that he had a secret stash of his own hidden deep among piles of junk and other crap. I’d really like to find him some day and beat the info out of him, but it seems like his secret went together with him to the grave.

It probably won’t be long until either of us gets tasked with recovering information deep down in some derelict laboratory. X18 is manageable… X16 is tougher on your psyche, and has more humanoids to fill with an extra hole or two.

If you have a job that requires you to get to either Jupiter or the eastern part of Pripyat and its outskirts, use the underpass to make it past the Pripyat undetected; you won’t have to deal with the fanatics aboveground. You’ll most likely have to deal with just mutants and zombies.

Be wary of machine gun nests scattered around certain strongholds and strategical locations. The gunner obviously can’t hit you when you’re facing his back, so sneaking up to him is a valid strategy as long as you don’t screw up and make yourself known to everyone around him. Usually, everyone will be in enough of a panic to not take over the fallen gunner’s position. Don’t forget about grenades, as well: a well placed throw can be enough to take one out if you’re in a pinch and can’t move out of cover.

If you feel like taking a long stroll, or taking out an outpost on your way to the bandit base in the Dark Valley, then I suggest turning east in the Cordon and going that way until you reach the Darkscape. Sometimes a squad or two may also be on patrol there, but watch out for the mutants anyway. It’s a relatively quiet place, but those mutant shits don’t care where to breed. As for the outpost I mentioned earlier, it is located approximately in the middle, right where the road curves.

Looking for some info, eh? I can tell you that as long as you remain under our protection, the mercenaries will not lay a finger on you. We are not worthy enough of being the target of their contractors, because the previous leaders have been taken out… They’ve perished, vanished, kissed their life goodbye, whatever you want to call it. No one is looking to step up to take leadership again, and besides, we’d bitch too much about this and that being wrong. The only person so far keeping a watch over a small area is Sultan, but his hand obviously doesn’t extend far enough to reach every single bandit across the entire Zone.

Are you feeling like taking someone’s ripe life? The loners have always been a prime choice for that. We’ve been pissing them off since the dawn of time, and those jackasses have always deserved to be messed around with. Most aren’t armed with great weaponry, but they do hate us enough to put up a nice fight, so you can get both decent equipment and combat practice from them.

Hey, have you ever seen an orange midget making his way through dense reeds? I sure have, and those garbage bags stand out so well that you can spot a scientist a mile away without even needing to use your binoculars. Recently, I’ve noticed that they’ve been using colour variations that look less like the vomit inducing rubbish those scientists usually get issued.

The only things that have less brains in their heads than those mongrel loners are the members of the Monolith faction. It’s amusing to hear tales about them and their actions; they seem like the Zone’s version of retards who can think about only one thing and nothing else. Too bad that their stupidity makes them fear death less.

Man, I remember tales about how long ago, some guys sporting a scorpion on their patches kicked the shit out of some boys in blue pyjamas. Everyone here always jokes about them and their clothing because they were weaker than a blind baby bloodsucker crawling in its nest… Oh, wait, now that I remember, that does make sense… All the eggheads were terrible at holding guns in their hands. They just don’t know how to live on what the Zone gives them.

If only you knew what I’d give for a mutant wave large enough to overrun Rostok. Every single time when we try to get near it, we get kicked out of it by those fools in black and red. They’ve settled in there real well; even managed to set up a pair of PKMs to ward off intruders like us. They’re armed pretty well, but their command structure… He-he, they’re not the purest out of all in the Zone. Plenty of secret deals between us and Duty, but now they want everyone to keep their mouths shut, and they don’t want to see our mugs close to theirs. God knows when they’ll stop throwing a tantrum about their scarred pride.

Freedom used to boast about their strength and “freedom in the Zone.” We showed them just what freedom can do out here and they had to move their sorry asses far away from us. These days, they’ll want you to think otherwise, and that they switched bases because it’s “safer from the mutants” or that “we can perform our duty of keeping the invaders at bay more easily.” Remember, pal: it’s all bullshit. They just don’t want to admit that we struck fear deep into their ranks.

The army boys don’t show up as much as they used to back in the day. Word has spread that their operations have gone down the gutter. I definitely wouldn’t feel great being commanded by some wanker who just wants me to rip a mutant pack or a stalker group apart only for his own benefit. They have it tough, sure, but it looks like their failures have actually managed to knock some sense into their skulls.

The advent of artefacts and their in-depth studying sometimes leaves me wondering how much worse things can get. These things possess untold properties, some so devastating that their incorporation into weapons could surpass anything made so far. Just imagine what a bomb built upon the harnessed energy of various kinds of artefacts could do!

I find it ironic how Freedom is the faction that keeps talking about the need to let everyone make use of the Zone, while Duty are the ones who come to Yantar to protect us and give artefacts to our leading scientists in order to help them with finding new ways to extinguish the Zone’s life.

The bandits keep taking hostages to extort money and various valuables. They don’t care about honesty and keeping their word, not to forget about the fact that they act like idiots and the lowest forms of life. They have it better when someone smarter comes along, although they’ve been keeping low for a while now, and no dedicated leader has stepped up yet to take control of every bandit establishment around the whole Zone. Right now, they’re mostly sticking to small and organised groups scattered about, which makes it harder to instil confusion and panic amongst them when someone important draws their last breath.

Some places can look more foreboding than they really are. The Agroprom underground serves as an example to this, because right now, various parts of it are closed off, and the mutants don’t have a lot of places to infest. I don’t suggest going there unless you either want to dump your equipment or actually try to scavenge something from all the junk that’s lying around. Stashing your loot in a backpack in a hard to reach place aboveground would be a better idea anyway.

The Zone can be fascinating at times. Just watching the world below you when you’re sitting atop a watchtower or another tall structure, with all the life running around, the wonderful formations the anomalies create, listening to the soothing music playing over at the 100 Rads while watching night taking over day’s place… That’s what I like about the Zone: it’s fatal, but beautiful at the same time.

If I’m still going to have to sit here and do nothing other than pellet some puny mutants with my weapon, then I’m going to have to reconsider my choice of joining Duty. Every day I get pushed around to do this and that, but what do I get? Barely anything. I’ve been here for long enough to be dispatched to far more dangerous areas, but it looks like a bunch of other guys have fallen into the same hole that I have. It’s almost as if the top brass doesn’t want to get down to really serious things and is just sitting safely in their bases until an opportunity comes so close that it can knock them out of their chairs.

Freedom may seem like a bunch of lunatics and people who are lazily sitting on their asses, but they can be pretty slick when the need to be such comes to them. They’ve managed to spread misinformation about us before to reduce the faith of other stalkers in Duty. Besides that, they also keep on saying how protecting the barrier is their doing and how much better it makes them than us. Don’t even think about believing their bullshit; they haven’t been protecting the barrier that long, and they’ve never played a large enough role in it… until they came over to crash at the warehouses, that is. We’ll get back at them for trying to create a larger figure of authority about this “defending” at a later time.

I’ve seen a lot of things in the Zone during my travels here, and most of it has come from the times when I wasn’t a part of Duty. Hell, the military stalkers are probably the toughest you’ll ever meet, bar the lunatics who keep pouring in from the north. Unlike the military forces who don’t go that deep into the Zone or haven’t been here long enough, they have received special training, or have experienced enough themselves; they possess equipment that easily outmatches that of most. They’re fierce opponents in battle, sure, but if you’re enough of a hotshot, you can try taking them out on your own… though I wouldn’t suggest doing so even if our ties with military stalkers are far, far more loose than the ones with the regular soldiers.

I’m sick of how everyone perceives us to be just a collective of potheads gathered around to do nothing other than praising the Zone and its creations. We really do try to spread useful information that we’ve acquired to those that need it, and we take hostile action when it’s needed and when there’s enough danger, unlike Duty, which likes to tell everyone otherwise while they’re acting like a bunch of tough kids who do nothing other than beat up pathetic bandits and weak mutants when they’re not just sitting at their base shooting up dogs.

One of the figures that we consider to be rather important is Forester. He has a keen eye on finding various paths through the dense forest, but, alas, his old age has got the best of him… He can’t help himself that much outside his safe haven any more. He provided valuable assistance to Scar, thus being able to provide help to Lebedev. Forester can still be found in the Red Forest… I believe that he’ll remain there for the rest of his life until he withers away enough to remain as just a memory imprinted in our minds.

A couple of years ago, we were led by Lebedev. Those were dog days, until a merc came along and helped us get our footing in the Swamps. But then, the whole Strelok thing got out of hand. Most of Clear Sky followed Lebedev and the merc north to sort it all out… Well, you know how that went. Anyway, we keep hearing about the death trucks in the Cordon, bringing back old friends. On the rare occasion, there are some signs of life, but it’s like they’ve had a massive stroke or something.

New in the Zone? Listen to yourself; you almost sound like one of those bastards out there. Information, huh… Ever heard of Major Kuznetsov? He was a real piece. After he replaced Major Khaletskiy for the trouble he was causing, Kuznetsov goes and does the same thing! It’s always the high ranking officers that are corrupted. They get a little taste of power and control, and then start trying to make extra on the side through the criminals here in the Zone! I heard he met with a terrible fate when he crossed paths with that one guy… I can’t recall his name, but they picked him up in Pripyat. Heard it was because he had some real important information.

We’ve got more guys getting dropped in later in the month. Just waiting for the Zone to give us some quiet time so the pilots can make it in and out. Rumour has it there are some French, Finnish, and British operatives coming in this time… Should be interesting.

Things may be rough out here, but it doesn’t mean the research has stopped. We’re managing with handmade gear, and now and again, we manage to grab equipment from the scientists. You’d be surprised at what we know about anti-coagulation from bloodsuckers and lens repair from flesh eyes.

We’re still losing friends to the Brain Scorcher. You hear about veterans who have taken drugs or put a bucket on their head… They endure the headaches and hallucinations and manage to actually grab some loot and artefacts and make it back to the camp in one piece. Of course, sometimes they can barely talk, or they’re losing their marbles. But people see them celebrating or retiring, and they decide to do the same.

They say there’s work at Yantar near the psi-field, if you’re dumb enough. They need to test out drugs and suits in order to push forward and make for the north. Trouble is, there’s no guarantee of you coming back. They say your head boils and your body doesn’t work properly; you start to hallucinate or lose your speech. Your best friend might suddenly be your worst enemy. It’s probably the most dangerous job out there right now.

The Brain Scorcher, man. There’s a big race to find a way through it, whether it’s by using a suit, or finding some sort of tunnel past the thick of it. Of course, everyone from the scientists to the military want to find a way past it, and whoever gets there first is going to get a treasure trove of artefacts, loot, and information.

Man, I miss the old base back in the Dark Valley. The area was creepy as shit sometimes, but we had a pretty good camp back then. But as soon as the bandits started wandering round from the Garbage, it got harder and harder to keep a footing there. Duty would push, and the bandits would press, and then in the end, we’d be losing guys and outposts like water through a sieve. Still, at least we’re set up here. We can go to sleep at night and only have to deal with the weird dreams… and possibly a hangover in the morning.

You tried any of the local cuisine yet? There’s some pretty messed up wildlife out there, but you can make a pretty good meal out of the flesh and boars. I’ve even heard about some of these guys eating snork hands… I mean, isn’t that cannibalism? Then there are bloodsucker tentacles or flesh eyes. It’s like some of the veterans don’t know about canned food.

So I went out on a job with one of the older guys the other day; they’ve been here for years, and you can see it. He was telling me about how his squad got stuck in a space anomaly. Yeah, it wasn’t fatal like the Whirligigs or Burners, but it trapped them for days… Just stuck in the same patch of grass with no supplies or communications.

There are some pretty rough patrols out there, and then some cosy ones. If you get the Great Swamps, then you’ll usually have aerial support from a chopper, and the outposts we hold tend to be pretty comfortable for a wasteland. But the stalkers and bandits who reside there will sometimes make a push and try and grab some land. So long as you keep your head down, the chopper usually scatters them. The Darkscape is the road heading north-east from here up to the Dark Valley. It’s pretty grim over there, with the bandits constantly trying to ambush anyone using the road, and the mutants really stirring up at night. Then there’s Agroprom. Agroprom is a mixed bag. You’ve got our military facility to bunk up at in the evening, but if you have to go out on patrol, you’ll be clashing with stalkers on your left and then getting attacked by mutants on your right. Moral of the story? Stick to the Cordon.

So when the Zone first… erm… erupted?… Anyway, we were constantly babysitting the scientists who were getting flown in. They’d have these tiny little bunkers full of science-y crap and then they’d tip toe outside in these stupid rubber suits. Meanwhile, we’re all in fatigues, caked in mud with nowhere to sleep or take shelter in. Every night, the sky would be bright red, and any patrol caught out in the wilds would come back as zombies. We’d get picked off by bloodsuckers and blown apart by anomalies, and all the while, these eggheads were more concerned about their research and artefacts. In the end, we bailed. We moved to Agroprom and sent over minimal support from time to time. Now, the scientists realise they can’t just rely on other people to take their bullets. They’ve got themselves armed with weapons, and their suits are starting to have thicker kevlar… and every night, I have a bunk and a bottle of vodka waiting for me. That’s justice.

I’m new here, but I’ve learnt a few things from the other guys. Always keep some bolts with you, preferably with string attached. We picked it up from the stalkers, originally. You throw the bolt ahead of you to check for anomalies. Sounds ridiculous, but in the Zone, it’s a lifesaver.

Be sure to grab any medical supplies from the stalkers or bandits you fight. They may not be sterile, or ideal for trauma compared to army or scientific medkits, but they can save your buddy when he’s downed. The friends you make in the Zone are the greatest friends you’ll ever have; always have a medkit spare.

We used to have a big problem with the renegades; outcasts who stumbled into the Swamps. We rallied together, and with help from Scar, we managed to kick their asses. Now the military have moved in, and they have themselves a chopper. Honestly, things seemed rough back then, but I really miss it. The military have really dug in deep.

There’s a real demand for tools in the Zone; more intricate gear for adjustments to weapons and suits. I found a set on some guy I shot a couple of months ago, but we had to stash them in a hurry. Not sure where they we hid them, but I’m sure a trader might have the coordinates if you do a few jobs for them.

Sometimes I like to sit in the camp, chill out and just listen to the radio, you know? It’s a reliable way to forget about all your problems and shit, even if for a second. Sometimes you need that little bit of escape and you gotta reach out to the outside world, otherwise the Zone will overwhelm you and you won’t be able to carry on no longer. And the radio gets the job done real well. The tricky question is where the fuck the signal is coming from… Maybe there’s this dude sitting by himself in a cosy shack on the fringes of the Zone who sends out a broadcast to keep people’s spirit up? Or maybe we’re being manipulated by the army? You know, subliminal messages and shit… I’d really like to know the story behind it.

Why are you here, Stalker? Some pieces of shit are here out of curiosity or even just for the hell of it. Knifing those bastards usually makes me very happy, but most of the time I stick to the job. You see, I’m here for the job, whatever that might be. I’d rape a fucking flesh if I could get some money out of it. See, I don’t care, I know what I’m here for, and none of these idealistic bastards could ever say that. So think about it. But don’t think too much or you might end up in a ditch.

I wonder what those freaking “animal rights” activists would say about the way we treat animals here. Fuck, are those things even “animals”? I call them hell spawns, and I usually shoot them in the face, because that’s what you do to hell spawns, you don’t protect them, feed them or, God forbid, nurture them. You fill ’em with lead and you move along before their friends arrive.

You want excitement? Is this place too boring for you? Go say hello to a snork or a bloodsucker. If you’re polite enough, they won’t even get aggressive. It’s weird, I had this one friend, he robbed people for a living, and he was dead set on doing this shit. I haven’t seen him since but it sure is worth a try, don’t you think? It’s strange why not many people have tried this, it’s bound to work, you don’t even have to carry any weapons.

My grandfather fought for the country, my father died for this piece of land and I’d be damned if I let this black hole eat my motherland away. The last thing my grandfather said before he succumbed to the crippling cancer was that I need to take care of my land. That is what I’m doing here, or rather was what I was supposed to be doing here. Things have changed now, I’m not even sure who I’m supposed to fight for. I had to put a bullet through the spine of a good friend of mine. The fool didn’t “believe” in emissions, so when a psionic storm hit, he was out gathering flowers or doing some other stupid shit. Afterwards, he went insane and started shooting at everyone and everything. I had to take him down. The same guy that I shared food with, the same guy that saved my ass every time I fucked up. What am I supposed to tell his kids now? Fuck this place.

They say that I made a mistake coming here. They’re a bunch of cowards. I’d rather be here than stuck behind some shitty desk. That’s what would really finish me off, not a mutated puppy, but mindless, endless paperwork. Demons live inside those gigantic stacks of papers, not under Pripyat sewers. This is where I belong, and this place is where I can actually be myself. Camo suits me much better than any tie, and a rifle speaks in a much clearer voice than any “president” or “director.”

Check the sky and the surroundings as often as you can. The moment you don’t look, all hell will break loose, emissions will appear and mutants will bite your ass off. Fight sleepiness by taking caffeine, eating food, just do whatever you need to do to keep awake. I sleep for only two or three hours a day, and always with a shooter beside me. This is something you either do, or you don’t, and if you don’t, you’ll be pushing up daisies in no time. Keep that in mind and get your shit together.

People do drugs here, it’s shit and it fucks them up real bad, but you do whatever you can to survive. If that means doing coke probably cut with detergent, then it’s coke and detergent all the way. I’ve seen some guys that won’t even touch the food unless they’re high on some crap. I’d wager if they don’t get their daily fix, they would rather starve to death than eat food that usually smells of dog piss. Junkies don’t live long enough here though. If you get addicted, the first thing you start doing is thieving, later you join the bandits, but soon enough you start thieving from them, and that’s when your life story ends and you get cut up like a pig or thrown into a snork hole. Don’t fuck with the bandits, and don’t fuck with drugs “too much.”

When that cold sweat hits you after you haven’t eaten for more than a day, that is exactly when your immune system goes on a fritz and you won’t be able to hold a pencil steady, let alone a machine gun. People start hallucinating and walk into trouble or right off a cliff. Fill your belly at least once a day, and if you can’t afford Beard’s delicious delicacies, then eat some worm-infested meat that you cut out from a mutant. Worms are cheap when compared to, well… death. I’ve seen people outside survive whole months without food, but here it’s another story. The Zone drains you. Drains your spirit, your willpower and your body. Don’t hesitate to feast on snorks if you really have to. Cannibalism isn’t exactly welcome, but if nobody sees you, it shouldn’t really be a problem.

I’ve seen grown men turn into crying babies here. They just can’t keep up and succumb to the pressure. Even athletes and people with superb physical condition drop like flies after a few squats here in the Zone. This place is a thief, and a very nasty one at that; it takes away a part of your soul every day, and doesn’t give it back. I could easily lift 30 kilos before I came here. Now I can barely lift a grenade when faced with a swarm of those tushkanos. It might be fear too, but whatever it is, it’s like a heavy burden we all carry, we all share. Next time you want to drop a bandit when you have the upper hand, remember what I said about the burden, he is carrying it too, just like you.

Next time you face a pack of dogs, try running directly towards them, it might actually save your ass from turning into dog food. We eat them, they eat us, it’s a symbiotic thing. But yeah, feel free to try it out, but leave your weapons behind so you’ll be able to run faster and be more intimidating. You might just leave them with me, I can keep them safe while you try this out for yourself. This shit works, but most Stalkers are fucking cowards and don’t have the balls for it.

Get a good knife, best one of those that could shave boar’s balls by looks alone. You know, quality brand knives. Get some oil on the knife, make it nice and shiny so that you can see your reflection in it. Then stab some poor fool in the throat, plunge the knife all the way to the hilt and wiggle it a bit. Soon enough, he will start bleeding out and losing consciousness, but, just a moment before he does, stare deep into his eyes. That way, your face, the face of his killer, will be the last thing he ever sees, he will take it to the grave, and the underworld will know about you. I’ve done this countless times, and I bet down under the ground they know my name and surname by now. When they know about you there, there is no reason to send their minions for you. I myself haven’t seen a freaking bloodsucker for months now; they already know about me. This is why I will survive longer than those other cowards.

I played the violin back home. Was one of the best, I even had the chance to meet the president twice. I knew the strings so well I could caress them in ways other violinists could only dream of. When I was recruited in the army, I thought I’d do my duty, go through a couple of years for my country, then get back to doing what I love. They sent me here, right after bootcamp, and I’ve been here ever since. Back home, they expect me to return to my previous glory and brilliance, but they don’t know what happened here. It’s this evil shit, the radiation or the Zone itself. It seeps into me each day, and my hands tremble, my bones hurt. I play some guitar once in a while, but that piece of rotten wood sounds like chimera claws ripping your guts. But that’s the only way to keep my sanity. I feel that the guitar takes me back a bit closer to the beauty of before, the strings, the music, but at the same time it hurts me deeply knowing that I could never be that person again. If only I had a violin here, any would do, I could maybe once again take a whiff of the time before I died inside.

Before all these scientists and mechanics came to the Zone, Stalkers used to carry artifacts on these makeshift belts with crude boxes attached to them. A whole generation of Stalkers are now sterile and slowly dying, their insides turning into liquid that they have to puke out once in a while. I don’t know how they stay sane, how they don’t just off themselves. If those simple boxes were damaged even a tiny bit, the radiation slowly entered their bodies, and that happened quite often. Now we have artifact containers that are quite durable. I’ve seen bullets deflecting of those contraptions, they make them as rough as those black boxes on airplanes. We have it easy now, think about the first wave of Stalkers that conquered the Zone, they were the true heroes. They didn’t have any manuals nor the tools and couldn’t enjoy the comfort of bases. Left completely on their own, they had to make up new ways to survive. Those boys were the pioneers.

I had this buddy who fought off two chimeras. Just imagine, in front of him there were two hulking monstrosities of flesh and claws, filled with a fair share of human flesh and craving for more. He was right to be afraid. He had his back to a wall, down on his last 20 buckshots and a few bombs. He was a good aim, but that is not why he survived. He had a few of these stimpacks. I call them boosters, because they sure work fast. Whenever the chimeras struck him down and he thought he couldn’t get up again, he would fix himself up with those things. Crafty fellow, that one. And you know, the human body is actually quite the resilient mother fucker. We aren’t usually used to life-threatening situations and we don’t have to fight off two-headed beasts to stay alive very often, but when we do, our body works wonders especially if you give it a tiny push. I don’t know what long term consequences those chemical nightmares have, but if you cared about long term consequences, you wouldn’t be prying around in the Zone in the first place.

Shit ain’t rosy outside either. My mom used to send me some cookies with sugar every few weeks and some letters telling me how they’re doing. She always keeps a brave face, writing how everything is just dandy and that they are quite content, but I can see that the cookies have less and less sugar every month, and the handwriting is getting worse too. At first, she used clean white paper, but now it’s this awful greasy paper probably found in some shit dumpster. I can’t summon up courage to ask how they’re really doing. I’m scared shitless of what they would say to me, even though I already know. I just don’t want to read about it. The mental image of my folks being OK is what keeps me going around here, I don’t care if it’s false, I’ve got nothing else anymore. I send them whatever money I earn. Yesterday I sent them some that I made by selling off the last of my food rations. I’d be OK, I can always try my luck at the anomaly casino. Losing a bet there isn’t the most healthy thing in the world but I’ll take my chances.

I’ve got it, man, I’ve got the bug. They told me like it didn’t mean shit to them, like reading a booklet about breeds of kittens. They told me I had AIDS and even told me to leave the room when I was still in shock. Fuck those people, you know? They study for so long to be perfect doctors, with a career and everything, but they end up being completely desensitized to everything. Like talking to a snork. The snork would’ve reacted in a more humane manner, this shit ain’t right. And I have to pay heaps of money every month to get the anti-retrovirals. That shit does not come cheap, not even that knockoff Chinese shit that is only available in the Zone. I might be getting placebo pills for all I know, I still feel like crap. The Zone is the best I can do right now. And here I am, 3 years and counting. But I see you have your own shit to take care of, so just walk away like everyone does. Just leave me the fuck alone.

Money. Cash. Heaps of notes with as many zeros as possible. I can see your eyes light up like an emission. So I guess I have your attention now. But it’s no walk in the park, and not everyone does it, and that is why it’s so rewarding. I don’t tell this shit like this to everyone, you know? But you look like the right guy, so listen up. Listen very carefully and try to remember every single word I tell you. What you should do to get filthy rich very quickly is: “WORK HARD AND DON’T WHINE ALL THE TIME.” You lazy fucking bastard. Bugger off and go mind your own bloody business.

The moment I took a single step inside the Zone was the first moment I felt really free. It was also the first moment I’ve ever realized that I didn’t feel free back home. I thought I was fine working at the docks, bringing in some good money, joking around with friends. I had the average Joe’s dream life. Some people think I must be insane for abandoning all that for the Zone. Some get really angry, one little shit even tried to shoot me. They don’t know how to enjoy life, how to breathe in a new day, with new possibilities and new challenges. I know it’s hard, but if you manage to survive here, even a single day, you’ve done more than any of the people back home would ever do. We’ve lost it, man, as humanity, we’ve been over-civilized, and have lost what it means to be alive. You are constantly reminded of it here, but back home you simply don’t realize it. Just yesterday I was taking a dump in some bushes, like a real Stalker, and these bees just appeared. Angry little bitches. So I covered my face with my gasmask and started to run as fast as hell. I was so focused on running that I ran directly into a herd of hungry dogs. This is how my day started, and those 5 kilometers I ran were the daily reminder that I was alive and free.

There was this broad I knew, and I knew her well, if you know what I mean. But that bitch was just fucked up, she always kept tabs on me, checked where I was, kept calling me, leaving me strange messages. I told her this shit between us wouldn’t work. She went fucking insane and started hitting me. See, I have nothing against hitting a woman, actually it’s quite a relief of pent up frustration, especially with a psycho like that bitch. So I left her in front of the hospital. I think that was cool enough of me, right? I know some guys that would bury her corpse or chop her up so she could fit in the drains. I’m a good guy, you see, I take care of my bitches, but when they give me shit, that’s it, I snap. Fuck, I’d really want to do her right now.

Don’t wait for the siren before an emission. The sirens are always too late and if you’re not close to any solid structure, you will get fried quite nicely. To stay alive and to avoid being fried, keep an eye towards the sky. If you see this odd cumulonimbus cloud formation, haul ass. And be quick about it. If a snork lair is your only option, go for it. You’d love those snorks compared to what the emission would do to you. So remember, when a thick vertical cloud formation appears in the sky looking as if God is puking his entrails from up above, that is when you say goodbye to all your heavy items, and sprint towards a safe spot. I had this one guy that wanted to have a tour around the Zone, he was some rich brat, constantly high on some shit and drunk. Well, that prick had the an opportunity to witness an incoming emission, and instead of taking cover like non-idiots like us, he stayed outside to admire the “beauty of the emission.” His exact words. As I said, he was quite rich, so I picked up some nice loot from his scarred carcass and one torn picture of a cute girl. Shit, that photo is probably doing the rounds right now among the Stalkers.

This place isn’t made for the likes of me. I’m not made for the likes of this place. I’m talking about the world, not the Zone. I’ve been having these clusterfuck migraines since I was little. My folks thought I was lying all the time and told me to “suck it up.” Only when I started bleeding from my ears on a regular basis they started to take notice. It was all too late naturally, I was much older then, and I decided to pack my things and say hi to the Zone and goodbye to the outside world. And guess what? My migraines miraculously disappeared once I came here. I was overjoyed. For the first time ever I could feel this weight lifted off my shoulders, it felt very liberating. I could smell things, I could focus my eyes well and concentrate on the good things for a change. So I started really enjoying my life when I actually came to what many people call hell. Most were perplexed by my demeanor and I made some enemies along the way. You can’t fit in over here unless you have that dreary, miserable outlook. They wouldn’t accept me as one of them, neither Duty nor Freedom. I took it upon myself to find somewhere to live, further away from the pessimism of regular Stalkers. I stayed in this makeshift hut I built of metal parts, buried under some concrete slabs. I was quite content, and the place seemed to shield me from emissions quite well, but there was this familiar feeling coming back to me. It even made me feel a bit nostalgic, before I realized the migraines were coming back. Now they are worse than before, my ears burn up, I can’t see well, and I can barely hold a gun because of those clusterfucks. I just want everything to end right now.

Holy shit, I can’t take this anymore. The ladies, I really miss ’em. I had a ton of girls back home, they liked the muscular types, I liked the big-boobs type. We had an understanding. But here, I haven’t even seen a female nipple! And I’m not touching those magazines Beard sells. They’re all greasy and sticky, I don’t want to know how they became that way. There were so many women in this place before 1986, before it became a radioactive desert. Parties, music. Communist music, but music nonetheless. Now I get turned on by their ghosts. I think about how many fish there were in the pond at Skadovsk or Yanov. I bet there was enough tail to last a lifetime. This is bullshit, I gotta get laid. Hey, on a completely unrelated matter, do you know where that herd of fleshes was killed recently? I’m actually going for a walk.

Have you heard about that quick release system? That thing saved my ass when I ran into a massive herd of boars and fleshes. I took some very, very nice loot from what looked like a Duty graveyard. There were literally dozens of bodies along with all their equipment, guns, artifacts, I couldn’t believe my eyes. I actually had to leave some artifacts behind, and I never do that, ever. But I was packed to the gills, and felt like a mule right before his back snapped. So it’s time to cash it in, I thought. While I was slowly walking towards the base, I was mumbling to myself: “not now, please not now, just not today, please,” and then the low pitched roar of a boar cut my prayers in half. I started running away from the sound, but this air is not good enough for that. It was like made of 95% nitrogen, and each time I breathed in, I choked. So I had to make a decision, I had to leave the loot. When that backpack slammed to the ground like a fucking meteor, I sprang forward like a gazelle with grace and whatnot, the air had oxygen in it once again. Later I came back to the stash, some artifacts were missing, but there was also some blood and a nice chunk of what looked like human flesh near it. Someone tried to take a swipe at the backpack, but was probably hunted down by those boars. Maybe they were guarding it while I was gone. I have newfound respect for boars. Haven’t eaten boar meat since.

Sometimes you’ll find some real nice food. You could snack on some nuts, fairly good meat or clean bread. But there are other times, whenever those emissions hit hard and often, where restocking isn’t so easy, so the choices are either to eat shit, or dine on some shit. The irradiated chops Beard sells at his place will fill your belly no prob, but you gotta take care of those radiated particles. Remember to wash them down with something clean, like water or something stronger. There was this fat bastard that chugged down some 20 pieces of this infested grilled shit. He was so fucked up later, other Stalkers had to feed him antirad pills, and he had to pay them back later. Even eating food is dangerous here, so watch what you stuff in your mouth and you should be “almost fine” most of the time.

I’m an ex-military, trained by the best, conditioned to be a killing machine. I might look thin and scrawny, but underneath there are resilient and strong muscles. You wouldn’t know what I’m talking about, I could break your neck before you could say “ouch.” Just don’t fuck with me and you’ll be fine. I’ve rammed into so many boars with my fists, I don’t waste ammo on those beasts. I punch them in their ugly muzzles until they just give up on life. I could show you if I wasn’t so busy all the time. You should man up, do some push-ups, don’t be such a chickenshit, huh? I’m sick of everyone asking for my help in taking down this chimera or sniping that controller from afar. I’d break this controller’s neck, I don’t snipe things like a coward. For me, it’s only close and personal. Sadly, not everyone respects what I do. Some of those bitchy Stalkers would tell you that I’m making all this up. Don’t you believe a word that comes out of their filthy lying mouths, they’re simply jealous of my strength and prowess. Just don’t tell them that I said this, OK?

What, you think you can just walk here and I’ll start spilling my guts like a little baby? Everyone else might be doing it, just waiting for some poor sod to walk by and ask them how they’re doing, but fuck you, friend, I’m doing swell, and I don’t need anyone to hear my confessions. Now bugger off.
Just leave me be, I’ve got too many rads today, ain’t my day.

I was once a lot like you, frightened, helpless and just an awfully pitiful sight. I fixed my attitude immediately after I was almost raped by those boar tusks. They cut you open just for the fun of it, I saw that happen to my buddy, he kind of took one for the team, I guess. I was so scared, I threw away my gun and ran towards cover like crazy. The first thing you have to do is get one of those armors, some thick stuff that would protect you from this awful environment. The more things you put between you and the freaks and monsters of the outside, the higher chances you’ll have. There was this guy, he bought some modified exo, and just installed every single Kevlar piece he could find. He looked like a bloody Christmas tree and attracted a shitload of animals, but somehow he always got through. The cannon he was carrying sure helped increase his odds, but that exo with Kevlar works wonders here. I’m this close to getting one of those, if only I didn’t have to feed the leeches back home.

Never trust those doctor fuckups. My granddad and grandma both got butchered by a surgeon. It was officially attributed to something else, but that doc was fucking drinking before the op. He reeked of booze and my granddad had to be operated right then and there. These Zone doctors aren’t any better, they’d charge you and arm and a leg for fixing up a scratch, as if they’ve done a brain transplant twice. I take my chances and heal on my own. I’m just very careful not to get hurt, like obsessively careful, I don’t drink and I don’t take no drugs. But when I do get hurt, I just eat some good food, drink clean water and plop one of those emergency med kits. It usually is a bit cheaper, but most importantly if I fuck myself up, I’ll have only myself to blame. I really don’t want to end up like my grandparents, all cut up for no fucking reason.

I got one for you. NEVER STEAL FROM BASES. You can take anything you want everywhere else, whoever grabs it first, it’s theirs. We aren’t really fond of thieves around here. Even the bandits know to keep their hands off other people’s shit. But if you’re caught red-handed, you should feel lucky if you’ll only hanged by your intestines on a tree.

I have seen those chickenshits, too careful what they eat, go broke from buying all this imported delicacies. I have seen idiots throw up all the food they just bought, because they didn’t really care about the rads. Both of those fuckers are wrong. You need to have balance, Zen and whatnot, you know? As Aristotle said… nevermind that. When you can spare the time, swallow some shitty meat boiled in shittier stuff, and when you need to be “on the go,” imported is what you need. Remember this lesson, and maybe you’ll even save enough to buy yourself some shooter that won’t break down after three shots at some sucker.

Back in the military in my home country we used to stuff our feet into the shoes along with a cloth of some sort, no socks.
